nub.core

Class Node

  • java.lang.Object
    • nub.core.Node

  • public class Node
extends java.lang.Object
    A node encapsulates a 2D or 3D coordinate system, represented by a position(), an orientation() and magnitude(). The order of these transformations is important: the node is first translated, then rotated around the new translated origin and then scaled. This class API partially conforms that of the great libQGLViewer.

    Hierarchy of nodes

    The node position, orientation and magnitude are actually defined with respect to a reference() node. The default reference() is the world coordinate system (represented by a null reference()). If you setReference(Node) to a different node, you must then differentiate:
    • The local translation(), rotation() and scaling(), defined with respect to the reference() which represents an angle preserving transformation of space.
    • The global position(), orientation() and magnitude(), always defined with respect to the world coordinate system.

    A node is actually defined by its translation() with respect to its reference(), then by rotation() of the coordinate system around the new translated origin and then by a uniform positive scaling() along its rotated axes.

    This terminology for local (translation(), rotation() and scaling()) and global (position(), orientation() and magnitude()) definitions is used in all the methods' names and should be enough to prevent ambiguities. These notions are obviously identical when the reference() is null, i.e., when the node is defined in the world coordinate system (the one you are left with after calling a graph preDraw() method).

    Geometry transformations

    A node is useful to define the position, orientation and magnitude of an arbitrary object which may represent a point-of-view.

    Use matrix() to access the node coordinate system, as when drawing an object locally:

    // Builds a node at position (0.5,0,0) and oriented such that its Y axis is along the (1,1,1) direction
    Node node = new Node(new Vector(0.5,0,0), new Quaternion(new Vector(0,1,0), new Vector(1,1,1)));
    graph.pushModelView();
    graph.applyModelView(node.matrix());
    // Draw your object here, in the local node coordinate system.
    graph.popModelView();

    Use view() and projection(Graph.Type, float, float, float, float, boolean) when rendering the scene from the node point-of-view. Note these methods are used by the graph when a node is set as its eye, see Graph.preDraw().

    To transform a point from one node to another use location(Vector, Node) and worldLocation(Vector). To instead transform a vector (such as a normal) use displacement(Vector, Node) and worldDisplacement(Vector).

    Hierarchical traversals

    Hierarchical traversals of the node hierarchy which automatically apply the local node transformations described above may be achieved with Graph.render() or Graph.render(Object). Automatic traversals require overriding visit() or Graph.draw(Object, Node) and to instantiate a node attached to a graph which is referred to as attached node (see isAttached(Graph) and isDetached()).

    To instantiate an attached node use the node constructors that take a graph parameter or a (reference) node which in turn is attached to a graph. Once instantiated, a node cannot be attached nor detached, but a copy of it can (see attach(Graph) and detach()).

    Constraints

    One interesting feature of a node is that its displacements can be constrained. When a Constraint is attached to a node, it filters the input of translate(Vector) and rotate(Quaternion), and only the resulting filtered motion is applied to the node. The default constraint() is null resulting in no filtering. Use setConstraint(Constraint) to attach a constraint to a node.

    Classical constraints are provided for convenience (see LocalConstraint, WorldConstraint and EyeConstraint) and new constraints can very easily be implemented.

    Shapes

    A node shape can be set from a retained-mode rendering object, see shape(Object); or from an immediate-mode rendering procedure, see graphics(Object). Picking a node is done according to a pickingThreshold(). When picking a node it will be highlighted according to a highlighting() policy.

    Application Control

    Implementing an application control for the node is a two step process:
    • Parse user gesture data by overriding interact(Object...).
    • Send gesture data to the node by calling Graph.defaultHIDControl(Object...), Graph.control(String, Object...) or Graph.control(Node, Object...).

    Syncing

    Two nodes can be synced together (sync(Node, Node)), meaning that they will share their global parameters (position, orientation and magnitude) taken the one that has been most recently updated. Syncing can be useful to share nodes among different off-screen canvases.

      • isAttached

        public boolean isAttached(Graph graph)
        Tells whether or not this node belongs to the hierarchy (see Graph.render()). To test if the node is detach from any graph hierarchy call isAttached(null).

        Note that a call to children() never returns null if the node is attached to a graph, i.e., that graph will visit the node during traversal.

        See Also:
        isDetached(), Graph.render()

      • isDetached

        public boolean isDetached()
        Same as return isAttached(null).

        Note that a call to children() always returns null if the node is detached, i.e., the node is not available for graph traversal (see Graph.render()).

        See Also:
        isAttached(Graph), Graph.render()

      • set

        public void set(Node node)
        Sets position(), orientation() and magnitude() values from those of the node. The node graph(), reference() and constraint() are not affected by this call.

        After calling set(node) a call to this.matches(node) should return true.

        See Also:
        reset(), worldMatrix()

      • reset

        public void reset()
        Sets an identity node by resetting its translation(), rotation() and scaling(). The node graph(), reference() and constraint() are not affected by this call. Call set(null) if you want to reset the global position(), orientation() and magnitude() node parameters instead.
        See Also:
        set(Node)

        public int id()

      • colorID

        public int colorID()
        Uniquely identifies the node. Also the color to be used for picking with a color buffer. See: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2262100/rgb-int-to-rgb-python

        See Also:
        sync(Node, Node)

      • sync

        public static void sync(Node node1,
                        Node node2)
        If node1 has been more recently updated than node2, calls node2.set(node1), otherwise calls node1.set(node2). Does nothing if both objects were updated at the same time.

        This method syncs only the global geometry attributes (position(), orientation() and magnitude()) among the two nodes. The reference() and constraint() (if any) of each node are kept separately.

        See Also:
        set(Node)

      • isReference

        public boolean isReference(Node node)
        Returns true if node is reference() this node.

      • isAncestor

        public boolean isAncestor(Node node)
        Returns true if node is ancestor of this node.

                                 Node ancestor)
        Same as return successor.isAncestor(ancestor).

      • path

        public static java.util.List<Node> path(Node tail,
                                        Node tip)
        Returns an array containing a straight path of nodes from tail to tip. Returns an empty list if tail is not ancestor of tip.
        See Also:
        isAncestor(Node, Node)

      • reference

        public Node reference()
        Returns the reference node, in which this node is defined.

        The node translation(), rotation() and scaling() are defined with respect to the reference() coordinate system. A null reference node (default value) means that the node is defined in the world coordinate system.

        Use position(), orientation() and magnitude() to recursively convert values along the reference node chain and to get values expressed in the world coordinate system. The values match when the reference node is null.

        Use setReference(Node) to set this value and create a node hierarchy. Convenient functions allow you to convert coordinates and vectors from one node to another: see location(Vector, Node) and displacement(Vector, Node), respectively.

      • resetReference

        public void resetReference()
        Same as setReference(null).
        See Also:
        setReference(Node), resetConstraint()

      • setReference

        public void setReference(Node node)
        Sets the reference() of the node.

        The node translation(), rotation() and scaling() are then defined in the reference() coordinate system.

        Use position(), orientation() and magnitude() to express the node global transformation in the world coordinate system.

        Using this method, you can create a hierarchy of nodes. This hierarchy needs to be a tree, which root is the world coordinate system (i.e., null reference()). No action is performed if setting reference as the reference() would create a loop in the hierarchy.

      • children

        public java.util.List<Node> children()
        Returns the list a child nodes of this node. Only meaningful if this node isAttached(Graph) to a graph. Returns null if this node isDetached().

      • randomize

        public void randomize()
        Same as randomize(graph().center(), graph().radius(), graph().is3D()).

        Does nothing if the node isDetached().

        See Also:
        randomize(Vector, float, boolean), Vector.randomize(), Quaternion.randomize(), random(Graph), random(Vector, float, boolean)

      • randomize

        public void randomize(Vector center,
                      float radius,
                      boolean is3D)
        Randomized this node. The node is randomly re-positioned inside the ball defined by center and radius, which in 2D is a circumference parallel to the x-y plane. The orientation() is randomized by Quaternion.randomize(). The new magnitude is a random in old-magnitude * [0,5...2].
        See Also:
        randomize(), Vector.randomize(), Quaternion.randomize(), random(Graph), random(Vector, float, boolean)

      • random

        public static Node random(Graph graph)
        Returns a random node attached to graph. The node is randomly positioned inside the graph viewing volume which is defined by Graph.center() and Graph.radius() (see Vector.random()). The orientation() is set by Quaternion.random(). The magnitude is a random in [0,5...2].
        See Also:
        random(Vector, float, boolean), Vector.random(), Quaternion.random(), randomize(), randomize(Vector, float, boolean)

      • random

        public static Node random(Vector center,
                          float radius,
                          boolean is3D)
        Returns a random detached node. The node is randomly positioned inside the ball defined by center and radius (see Vector.random()), which in 2D is a circumference parallel to the x-y plane. The orientation() is set by Quaternion.random(). The magnitude is a random in [0,5...2].
        See Also:
        random(Graph), Vector.random(), Quaternion.random(), randomize(), randomize(Vector, float, boolean)

      • setPickingThreshold

        public void setPickingThreshold(float threshold)
        Sets the pickingThreshold().
        See Also:
        pickingThreshold(), setHighlighting(Highlighting)

      • pickingThreshold

        public float pickingThreshold()
        Returns the node picking threshold. Set it with setPickingThreshold(float).

        Picking a node is done with ray casting against a screen-space shape defined according to a pickingThreshold() as follows:

        • The projected pixels of the node visual representation (see graphics(Object) and shape(Object)). Set it with threshold = 0.
        • A node bounding box whose length is defined as percentage of the graph diameter (see Graph.radius()). Set it with threshold in [0..1].
        • A 'shooter target' of a fixed pixels length. Set it with threshold > 1.
        Default picking precision is defined with threshold = 0.2.
        See Also:
        setPickingThreshold(float), highlighting()

      • constraint

        public Constraint constraint()
        Returns the current Constraint applied to the node.

        A null value (default) means that no constraint is used to filter the node translation and rotation.

        See the Constraint class documentation for details.

      • setConstraint

        public void setConstraint(Constraint constraint)
        Sets the constraint() attached to the node.

        A null value means set no constraint (also reset it if there was one).

      • resetConstraint

        public void resetConstraint()
        Same as setConstraint(null).
        See Also:
        setConstraint(Constraint), resetReference()

      • translation

        public Vector translation()
        Returns the node translation, defined with respect to the reference().

        Use position() to get the result in world coordinates. These two values are identical when the reference() is null (default).

        See Also:
        setTranslation(Vector)

      • setTranslation

        public void setTranslation(Vector translation)
        Sets the translation() of the node, locally defined with respect to the reference().

        Note that if there's a constraint() it is satisfied, i.e., to bypass a node constraint simply reset it (see setConstraint(Constraint)).

        Use setPosition(Vector) to define the world coordinates position().

        See Also:
        setConstraint(Constraint)

      • setTranslation

        public void setTranslation(float x,
                           float y)
        Same as setTranslation(Vector), but with float parameters.

                      float y,

      • translate

        public void translate(float x,
                      float y)
        Same as translate(Vector) but with float parameters.

      • translate

        public void translate(Vector vector)
        Translates the node according to vector, locally defined with respect to the reference().

        If there's a constraint() it is satisfied. Hence the translation actually applied to the node may differ from vector (since it can be filtered by the constraint()).

        See Also:
        rotate(Quaternion), scale(float)

      • position

        public Vector position()
        Returns the node position defined in the world coordinate system.
        See Also:
        orientation(), magnitude(), setPosition(Vector), translation()

      • setPosition

        public void setPosition(Vector position)
        Sets the node position(), defined in the world coordinate system.

        Use setTranslation(Vector) to define the local node translation (with respect to the reference()).

        Note that the potential constraint() of the node is taken into account, i.e., to bypass a node constraint simply reset it (see setConstraint(Constraint)).

        See Also:
        setConstraint(Constraint)

        public void setPosition(float x,

      • rotation

        public Quaternion rotation()
        Returns the node rotation, defined with respect to the reference() (i.e, the current Quaternion orientation).

        Use orientation() to get the result in world coordinates. These two values are identical when the reference() is null (default).

        See Also:
        setRotation(Quaternion)

      • setRotation

        public void setRotation(float x,
                        float y,
                        float z,
                        float w)
        Same as setRotation(Quaternion) but with float Quaternion parameters.

      • setRotation

        public void setRotation(Quaternion rotation)
        Set the current rotation. See the different Quaternion constructors.

        Sets the node rotation(), locally defined with respect to the reference(). Use setOrientation(Quaternion) to define the world coordinates orientation().

        Note that if there's a constraint() it is satisfied, i.e., to bypass a node constraint simply reset it (see setConstraint(Constraint)).

        See Also:
        setConstraint(Constraint), rotation(), setTranslation(Vector)

      • rotate

        public void rotate(Quaternion quaternion)
        Rotates the node by quaternion (defined in the node coordinate system): rotation().compose(quaternion).

        Note that if there's a constraint() it is satisfied, i.e., to bypass a node constraint simply reset it (see setConstraint(Constraint)).

        See Also:
        setConstraint(Constraint), translate(Vector)

      • orbit

        public void orbit(Quaternion quaternion,
                  Node node)
        Rotates this node around node (which may be null for the world coordinate system) according to quaternion.

        The quaternion axes (see Quaternion.axis()) is defined in the node coordinate system.

        Note: if there's a constraint() it is satisfied, i.e., to bypass a node constraint simply reset it (see setConstraint(Constraint)).

        Use setRotation(Quaternion) to define the local node rotation (with respect to the reference()).

        Note that the potential constraint() of the node is taken into account, i.e., to bypass a node constraint simply reset it (see setConstraint(Constraint)).

        Sets the scaling() of the node, locally defined with respect to the reference().

        Use setMagnitude(float) to define the world coordinates magnitude().

        public void scale(float scaling)
        Scales the node according to scaling, locally defined with respect to the reference().
        See Also:
        rotate(Quaternion), translate(Vector)

      • magnitude

        public float magnitude()
        Returns the magnitude of the node, defined in the world coordinate system.

        Note that the magnitude is used to compute the node projection(Graph.Type, float, float, float, float, boolean) which is useful to render a scene from the node point-of-view.

        See Also:
        orientation(), position(), setPosition(Vector), translation(), projection(Graph.Type, float, float, float, float, boolean)

      • setMagnitude

        public void setMagnitude(float magnitude)
        Sets the magnitude() of the node, defined in the world coordinate system.

        Use setScaling(float) to define the local node scaling (with respect to the reference()).

        Same as align(move, null).

      • align

        public void align(float threshold)
        Same as align(threshold, null).

        public void align(float threshold,
                  Node node)
        Convenience function that simply calls align(false, threshold, node).
        See Also:
        align(boolean, float, Node)

      • align

        public void align(boolean move,
                  float threshold)
        Same as align(move, threshold, null).
        See Also:
        align(boolean, float, Node)

      • align

        public void align(boolean move,
                  float threshold,
                  Node node)
        Aligns the node with node, so that two of their axis are parallel.

        If one of the X, Y and Z axis of the Node is almost parallel to any of the X, Y, or Z axis of node, the Node is rotated so that these two axis actually become parallel.

        If, after this first rotation, two other axis are also almost parallel, a second alignment is performed. The two nodes then have identical orientations, up to 90 degrees rotations.

        threshold measures how close two axis must be to be considered parallel. It is compared with the absolute values of the dot product of the normalized axis.

        When move is set to true, the Node position() is also affected by the alignment. The new Node position() is such that the node node position (computed with location(Vector), in the Node coordinates system) does not change.

        node may be null and then represents the world coordinate system (same convention than for the reference()).

      • projectOnLine

        public void projectOnLine(Vector origin,
                          Vector direction)
        Translates the node so that its position() lies on the line defined by origin and direction (defined in the world coordinate system).

        Simply uses an orthogonal projection. direction does not need to be normalized.

      • setXAxis

        public void setXAxis(Vector axis)
        Rotates the node so that its xAxis() becomes axis defined in the world coordinate system. Attention: this rotation is not uniquely defined. See Quaternion.fromTo(Vector, Vector).
        See Also:
        xAxis(), setYAxis(Vector), setZAxis(Vector)

      • setYAxis

        public void setYAxis(Vector axis)
        Rotates the node so that its yAxis() becomes axis defined in the world coordinate system. Attention: this rotation is not uniquely defined. See Quaternion.fromTo(Vector, Vector).
        See Also:
        yAxis(), setYAxis(Vector), setZAxis(Vector)

      • setZAxis

        See Also:
        zAxis(), setYAxis(Vector), setZAxis(Vector)

      • matrix

        public Matrix matrix()
        Returns the local transformation matrix represented by the node.

        This method could be used in conjunction with pushMatrix(), popMatrix() and applyMatrix() to modify a graph modelView() matrix from a node hierarchy. For example, with this node hierarchy:

        Node body = new Node();
        Node leftArm = new Node();
        Node rightArm = new Node();
        leftArm.setReference(body);
        rightArm.setReference(body);

        The associated drawing code should look like:

        graph.pushModelView();
        graph.applyMatrix(body.matrix());
        drawBody();
        graph.pushModelView();
        graph.applyMatrix(leftArm.matrix());
        drawArm();
        graph.popModelView();
        graph.pushModelView();
        graph.applyMatrix(rightArm.matrix());
        drawArm();
        graph.popModelView();
        graph.popModelView();

        Note the use of nested pushModelView() and popModelView() blocks to represent the node hierarchy: leftArm and rightArm are both correctly drawn with respect to the body coordinate system.

        This matrix only represents the local node transformation (i.e., with respect to the reference()). Use worldMatrix() to get the full Node transformation matrix (i.e., from the world to the Node coordinate system). These two match when the reference() is null. Attention: In Processing this technique is inefficient because papplet.applyMatrix will try to calculate the inverse of the transform. Use Graph.applyTransformation(Node) instead.

        See Also:
        set(Node), worldMatrix(), view()

      • worldMatrix

        public Matrix worldMatrix()
        Returns the global transformation matrix represented by the node which grants direct access to it, without the need to traverse its ancestor hierarchy first (as it is the case with matrix()).

        This method should be used in conjunction with applyMatrix() to modify a graph modelView() matrix from a node:

        // Here the modelview matrix corresponds to the world coordinate system.
        Node node = new Node(translation, new Rotation(from, to));
        graph.applyModelView(node.worldMatrix());
        // draw object in the node coordinate system.

        This matrix represents the global node transformation: the entire reference() hierarchy is taken into account to define the node transformation from the world coordinate system. Use matrix() to get the local node transformation matrix (i.e. defined with respect to the reference()). These two match when the reference() is null.

        See Also:
        set(Node), matrix(), view()

      • view

        public Matrix view()
        Returns the inverse of the matrix associated with the node position and orientation that is to be used when the node represents an eye. This matrix matches the inverted of the worldMatrix() when scaling() is 1.

        The view matrix converts from the world coordinates system to the eye coordinates system, so that coordinates can then be projected on screen using a projection matrix.

        See Also:
        Matrix.view(Vector, Quaternion), matrix(), worldMatrix(), set(Node), set(Node)

      • fromMatrix

        public void fromMatrix(Matrix matrix)
        Sets the node from a matrix() representation: rotation and scaling in the upper left 3x3 matrix and translation on the last column.

        Hence, if your openGL code fragment looks like:

        float [] m = new float [16]; m[0]=...;
        gl.glMultMatrixf(m);

        It is equivalent to write:

        Node node = new Node();
        node.fromMatrix(m);
        graph.pushModelView();
        graph.applyModelView(node.matrix());
        // You are in the local node coordinate system.
        graph.popModelView();

        Which allows to apply local transformations to the node while using geometry data from other node instances when necessary (see location(Vector, Node) and displacement(Vector, Node)).

        See Also:
        fromWorldMatrix(Matrix), matrix()

      • projection

        public Matrix projection(Graph.Type type,
                         float width,
                         float height,
                         float zNear,
                         float zFar,
                         boolean leftHanded)
        Returns either perspective(width / height, zNear, zFar, lefTHanded) if the Graph.Type is Graph.Type.PERSPECTIVE or orthographic(width, height, zNear, zFar, lefTHanded), if the the Graph.Type is Graph.Type.ORTHOGRAPHIC or Graph.Type.TWO_D. In both cases it uses the node magnitude().

        Override this method to set a Graph.Type.CUSTOM projection.

        See Also:
        perspective(float, float, float, boolean), orthographic(float, float, float, float, boolean), magnitude()

      • orthographic

        public Matrix orthographic(float width,
                           float height,
                           float zNear,
                           float zFar,
                           boolean leftHanded)
        Same as return Matrix.orthographic(width * magnitude(), (leftHanded ? -height : height) * magnitude(), zNear, zFar.

        Note that to compute the orthographic matrix the node magnitude() scales the viewing volume width and height.

        See Also:
        Matrix.orthographic(float, float, float, float), perspective(float, float, float, boolean), magnitude(), projection(Graph.Type, float, float, float, float, boolean)

      • perspective

        public Matrix perspective(float aspectRatio,
                          float zNear,
                          float zFar,
                          boolean leftHanded)
        Same as return Matrix.perspective(leftHanded ? -magnitude() : magnitude(), aspectRatio, zNear, zFar).

        Note that to compute the perspective matrix the node magnitude() is taken as: tan(fov / 2), where fov stands for the frustum field-of-view.

        See Also:
        Matrix.perspective(float, float, float, float), orthographic(float, float, float, float, boolean), magnitude(), projection(Graph.Type, float, float, float, float, boolean)

      • fromWorldMatrix

        public void fromWorldMatrix(Matrix matrix)
        Sets the node from worldMatrix() representation: orientation and magnitude in the upper left 3x3 matrix and position on the last column.

        Hence, if your openGL code fragment looks like:

        float [] m = new float [16]; m[0]=...;
        gl.glMultMatrixf(m);

        It is equivalent to write:

        Node node = new Node();
        node.fromWorldMatrix(m);
        graph.applyModelView(node.matrix());
        // You are in the local node coordinate system.

        Which allows to apply local transformations to the node while using geometry data from other node instances when necessary (see location(Vector, Node) and displacement(Vector, Node)).

        See Also:
        fromMatrix(Matrix), worldMatrix()

      • inverse

        public Node inverse()
        Returns a node representing the inverse of this node space transformation.

        The new node rotation() is the Quaternion.inverse() of the original rotation. Its translation() is the negated inverse rotated image of the original translation. Its scaling() is 1 / original scaling.

        If a node is considered as a space rigid transformation, i.e., translation and rotation, but no scaling (scaling=1), the inverse() node performs the inverse transformation.

        Only the local node transformation (i.e., defined with respect to the reference()) is inverted. Use worldInverse() for a global inverse.

        The resulting node has the same reference() as the this node and a null constraint().

        See Also:
        worldInverse()

      • worldInverse

        public Node worldInverse()
        Returns the inverse() of the node world transformation.

        The orientation() of the new node is the Quaternion.inverse() of the original orientation. Its position() is the negated and inverse rotated image of the original position. The magnitude() is the original magnitude multiplicative inverse.

        The result node has a null reference() and a null constraint().

        Use inverse() for a local (i.e., with respect to reference()) transformation inverse.

        See Also:
        inverse()

      • displacement

        public Vector displacement(Vector vector)
        Converts vector displacement from world to this node. Same as return displacement(vector, null). location(Vector) converts locations instead of displacements.
        See Also:
        displacement(Vector, Node), location(Vector)

      • displacement

        public Vector displacement(Vector vector,
                           Node node)

        See Also:
        displacement(Vector), worldDisplacement(Vector)

        Converts vector displacement from this node to world. displacement(Vector) performs the inverse transformation. worldLocation(Vector) converts locations instead of displacements.
        See Also:
        location(Vector), displacement(Vector, Node)

      • location

        See Also:

        See Also:

      • graph

        public Graph graph()
        Returns the graph this node is attached to. Always returns false if the node isDetached().

      • enableTracking

        public void enableTracking(boolean flag)
        Enables node tracking according to flag. When tracking is disabled Graph.tracks(Point, Node) returns false, Graph.setTrackedNode(String, Node) does nothing while Graph.track(String, Point) and Graph.cast(String, Point) would bypass the node.
        See Also:
        isTrackingEnabled()

      • isTracked

        See Also:
        isDetached(), isTracked(Graph)

        See Also:

      • interact

        public void interact(java.lang.Object... gesture)
        Parse gesture params. Useful to implement the node as an for application control. Default implementation is empty. , i.e., it is meant to be implemented by derived classes.

      • visit

        public void visit()
        This method is called on each node of the graph hierarchy by the Graph.render() algorithm to visit it. Default implementation is empty, i.e., it is meant to be implemented by derived classes.

        Hierarchical culling, i.e., culling of the node and its children, should be decided here. Set the culling flag with cull(boolean) according to your culling condition: 

         {@code
 node = new Node(graph) {
        See Also:
        Graph.render(), Graph.render(), cull(boolean), isCulled(), Graph.draw(Object, Node)

      • cull

        public void cull()
        Same as cull(true). Only meaningful if the node is attached to a graph.
        See Also:
        cull(boolean), isCulled()

      • cull

        public void cull(boolean cull)
        Enables or disables visit() of this node and its children during Graph.render(). Culling should be decided within visit(). Only meaningful if the node is attached to a graph.
        See Also:
        isCulled()

      • isCulled

        public boolean isCulled()
        Returns whether or not the node culled or not. Culled nodes (and their children) will not be visited by the Graph.render() algorithm. Always returns false if the node isDetached().
        See Also:
        cull(boolean)

      • setHighlighting

        public void setHighlighting(Node.Highlighting highlighting)
        Sets the node highlighting().
        See Also:
        highlighting(), setPickingThreshold(float)

      • highlighting

        public Node.Highlighting highlighting()
        Returns the highlighting mode. Highlights the shape when picking takes place as follows:
        1. Node.Highlighting.NONE: no highlighting takes place.
        2. Node.Highlighting.FRONT: the front-shape (see frontShape(Object) and frontGraphics(Object)) is scaled by a 1.15 factor.
        3. Node.Highlighting.BACK: the back-shape (see backShape(Object) and backGraphics(Object)) is displayed instead of the front-shape.
        4. Node.Highlighting.FRONT_BACK: both, the front and the back shapes are displayed. The back shape is made translucent

        Default is Node.Highlighting.FRONT.

        See Also:
        setHighlighting(Highlighting), pickingThreshold()

      • graphics

        public boolean graphics(java.lang.Object context)
        Override this method to set an immediate mode graphics procedure on context. Return true if succeeded and false otherwise.

        Sets both the front and the back shape to the same graphics procedure. Override frontGraphics(Object) and backGraphics(Object) to set different graphics procedures for rendering and picking, respectively.

        See Also:
        frontGraphics(Object), backGraphics(Object), shape(Object)

      • frontGraphics

        public boolean frontGraphics(java.lang.Object context)
        Override this method to set an immediate mode graphics procedure to draw the front shape. Use it in conjunction with @see #backGraphics(Object). Return true if succeeded and false otherwise.
        See Also:
        graphics(Object), shape(Object)

      • backGraphics

        public boolean backGraphics(java.lang.Object context)
        Override this method to set an immediate mode graphics procedure to draw the shape used for picking. Use it in conjunction with @see #frontGraphics(Object). Return true if succeeded and false otherwise.
        See Also:
        graphics(Object), shape(Object)

      • shape

        public void shape(java.lang.Object shape)
        Sets the retained mode shape for both, the front and the back shapes. Call frontShape(Object) and frontShape(Object) to set different graphics for rendering and picking, respectively.
        See Also:
        frontShape(Object), backShape(Object), graphics(Object)

      • frontShape

        public void frontShape(java.lang.Object shape)
        Sets the retained mode shape for the front shape. Use it in conjunction with @see #backShape(Object)}.
        See Also:
        shape(Object), graphics(Object)

      • backShape

        public void backShape(java.lang.Object shape)
        Sets the retained mode shape used for picking. Use it in conjunction with @see #frontShape(Object)}.
        See Also:
        shape(Object), graphics(Object)

      • frontShape

        public java.lang.Object frontShape()

      • backShape

        public java.lang.Object backShape()

      • graphics

        public boolean graphics(PGraphics pGraphics)
        Override this method to set an immediate mode graphics procedure on the Processing PGraphics. Return true if succeeded and false otherwise.

        Sets both the front and the back shape to the same graphics procedure.

        See Also:
        frontGraphics(processing.core.PGraphics), backGraphics(processing.core.PGraphics)

      • frontGraphics

        public boolean frontGraphics(PGraphics pGraphics)
        Override this method to set an immediate mode graphics procedure to draw the front shape. Use it in conjunction with @see #backGraphics(processing.core.PGraphics). Return true if succeeded and false otherwise.
        See Also:
        graphics(processing.core.PGraphics)

      • backGraphics

        public boolean backGraphics(PGraphics pGraphics)
        Override this method to set an immediate mode graphics procedure to draw the shape used for picking. Use it in conjunction with @see #frontGraphics(processing.core.PGraphics). Return true if succeeded and false otherwise.
        See Also:
        graphics(processing.core.PGraphics)
